content.webTitle: BBC receives warning over bias from John Whittingdale

fields.headline: BBC receives warning over bias from John Whittingdale
fields.bodyText: The process for dealing with accusations of bias at the BBC could be re-examined, according to the culture secretary John Whittingdale, who suggested the broadcaster may be judged by an external regulator. Speaking to the Daily Telegraph, Whittingdale, an outspoken critic of the BBC, said a “very robust system” was needed to ensure the broadcaster’s coverage was impartial. “Whether or not the present governance is the right way of dealing with it – the fact that questions of impartiality are judged by the BBC Trust – that is an area which I want to think about, because all the other broadcasters have an external regulator looking at the impartiality question,” he said. “It’s part of the bigger question of the way in which the BBC is governed.” The culture secretary said in the interview that he did not have a vendetta against the broadcaster. “I think the BBC has an incredibly difficult job, in that political parties are always going to be looking for signs that the BBC – indeed not just the BBC, but any broadcaster – is not acting in an wholly impartial way,” he said. “I think sometimes my party had cause for complaint. I suspect that it may well be the case that sometimes the Labour party had cause for complaint.” Conservative figures have complained of a leftwing bias at the BBC, an accusation that was recently rejected by corporation’s head of news, James Harding. Whittingdale, who is expected to take a tough stance against the BBC when charter renewal negotiations begin, said it needed to be made “fit for the new broadcasting age we are moving into”. When Whittingdale was named culture secretary, the Times and the Telegraph led with his appointment of their front pages, with the latter saying the Tories had gone to war with the BBC. But the culture secretary rejected this suggestion: “It never was the case that I was going in to go to war with the BBC … I am critical of the BBC. I also think there are areas where clearly there is a strong case for change, not least because the landscape is looking so different. But it isn’t a sort of vendetta or a punishment exercise or anything like that.” He would not be drawn on the future of BBC funding, but said he was waiting for the outcome of a report by David Perry QC into the possibility of decriminalising non-payment of the licence fee. He said: “If [David Perry] comes back and recommends going down that road – or if we decide to go down that road – that immediately has implications for the way the licence fee works. We’re waiting to see that report.” Explaining his famous comment that the licence fee was “worse than the poll tax”, he said: “It might be naivety, but I have a slight cause for surprise that it was regarded as such a controversial statement. Because what I was doing was stating what seems to me a statement of fact. “There are arguments for the licence fee and there are arguments against the licence fee. But one of the criticisms of the licence fee is that it is a flat-rate charge, which every household up to 75 has to pay. There is no assistance available – which actually under the [poll tax] there was. It takes no account of people’s income or wealth. It is in that sense highly regressive.”
